Jepang: 10 kereta cepat senilai Rp1,5 triliun dijadikan besi cacahan akibat terendam banjir Topan Hagibis
07 Nov 2019, 00:39 by BBC


Kereta api Hokuriku-Shinkansen kini terparkir di halaman di kota Nagano.

Sebanyak 10 kereta cepat Jepang yang terendam banjir imbas Topan Hagibis bulan lalu, kini dijadikan besi cacahan.
Beberapa komponen dari kereta-kereta yang harganya antara US$110 juta hingga US$135 juta (Rp1,5 triliun-Rp1,9 triliun) masih bisa digunakan, namun secara keseluruhan nilainya telah hilang.
Kereta api Hokuriku-Shinkansen kini diparkir di sebuah lapangan di kota Nagano.
Topan Hagibis melanda dengan kecepatan angin mencapai 225 km/jam pada 12-13 Oktober, menewaskan sekitar 90 orang dan membuat ribuan orang mengungsi.
Itu adalah badai terburuk di Jepang dalam beberapa dekade.
Foto-foto kereta yang terbengkalai terendam banjir, menjadi simbol besarnya kerusakan yang diakibatkan badai itu.


Topan Hagibis melanda dengan kecepatan 225 km/jam pada 12-13 Oktober.

Masing-masing kereta memiliki 12 rangkaian. Sebelum badai menerjang, sehari-hari kereta tersebut menempuh perjalanan di jalur Hokuriku-Shinkansen yang menghubungkan Tokyo dengan Kanazawa di pantai barat.
Presiden Perusahaan Kereta Api Jepang Timur, Yuji Fukasawa, mengatakan bahwa banjir telah merusak banyak komponen utama kereta, termasuk mesin penggerak dan sistem pengereman.
Dalam konferensi pers yang digelar hari Rabu (06/11) dia menyebut "dalam hal stabilitas dan keamanan sudah tepat" untuk menjadikan kereta itu sebagai rongsokan besi dan menggantinya dengan kereta baru.
Delapan kereta yang terendam banjir adalah milik perusahaannya. Dua lainnya, yang dimiliki oleh Perusahaan Kereta Api Jepang Barat, juga akan dijadikan besi cacah.
"Kami bertujuan untuk mengembalikan layanan 100% pada akhir tahun bisnis saat ini [pada bulan Maret]," kata Fukasawa.
Saat ini, layanan baru beroperasi sekitar 80%.

Japan: 10 high-speed trains worth Rp1.5 trillion are made into chopped iron due to flooding from Typhoon Hagibis
Nov 7 2019, 00:39 by BBC


The Hokuriku-Shinkansen train is now parked in the courtyard in the city of Nagano.

A total of 10 Japanese high-speed trains that were flooded by Typhoon Hagibis last month, are now made into chopped iron.
Some components of the trains that cost between US $ 110 million to US $ 135 million (Rp1.5 trillion-Rp1.9 trillion) can still be used, but overall the value has been lost.
The Hokuriku-Shinkansen train is now parked in a field in the city of Nagano.
Typhoon Hagibis struck with wind speeds reaching 225 km / h on October 12-13, killing around 90 people and displacing thousands of people.
It was the worst storm in Japan in decades.
Photographs of abandoned trains submerged by floods are a symbol of the amount of damage caused by the storm.


Typhoon Hagibis struck at 225 km / h on October 12-13.

Each train has 12 circuits. Before the storm hit, the train traveled daily on the Hokuriku-Shinkansen line that connects Tokyo with Kanazawa on the west coast.
The president of the East Japan Railroad Company, Yuji Fukasawa, said that the flood had damaged many of the main components of the train, including the engine and braking system.
In a press conference held on Wednesday (06/11) he said "in terms of stability and safety it was appropriate" to make the train a wreck of iron and replace it with a new train.
The eight flooded trains are the property of his company. The other two, which are owned by the West Japan Railroad Company, will also be made into chopped iron.
"We aim to restore services 100% at the end of the current business year [in March]," Fukasawa said.
At present, the new service operates around 80%.
